lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/app.Friday.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run app.Friday.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

Friday is your personal chatbot assistant designed to make task
management simple and intuitive. Instead of clicking through menus or
juggling multiple apps, you can chat naturally with Friday to keep
track of everything you need to do.
Add a todo task by typing `todo` followed by the task description.
After keying in the command line Friday will prompt you with a confirmation message.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have X tasks in the list.
Add a deadline task by typing `deadline` followed by the task description and due date.
After keying in the command line Friday will prompt you with a confirmation message.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have X tasks in the list.
Add an event task by typing `event` followed by the task description
and event start date and end date.
Example: `event (description of task) /from (start date:DD/MM/YYYY HHMM) /to (end date:DD/MM/YYYY HHMM) (Optional:#tag)`
After keying in the command line Friday will prompt you with a confirmation message.
Got it. I've added this task:
[E][ ] (description of task) /from (from: start date) /to (to: end date) (Optional:#tag)
Now you have X tasks in the list.
Delete a task by typing `delete` followed by the task number.
After keying in the command line Friday will prompt you with a confirmation message.
Now you have X tasks in the list.
Mark a task as done by typing `mark` followed by the task number.
After keying in the command line Friday will prompt you with a confirmation message.
Nice! I've marked this task as Done:
Unmark a task as not done by typing `unmark` followed by the task number.
After keying in the command line Friday will prompt you with a confirmation message.
OK, I've unmarked this task as Done:
After keying in the command line Friday will display all your tasks.
```Here are the tasks in your list:
Find tasks by typing `find` followed by a keyword.
After keying in the command line Friday will display all matching tasks.
Here are the matching tasks in your list:
Tag a task by adding `#tag` after the task description or deadline when adding a task.
After keying in the command line Friday will prompt you with a confirmation message.
Now you have X tasks in the list.

// Initially, the task should not be isDone
assertFalse(deadline.getIsDone(), "Task should start as not isDone");

* Test if the method testMarkAsUndone is working as intended.
// First mark the task as isDone
assertTrue(deadline.getIsDone(), "Task should be isDone before marking as undone");
assertFalse(deadline.getIsDone(), "Task should be undone after markTaskAsUndone()");

* Represents a class use to test the Todo class.
* Test if the method testMarkTaskAsDone is working as intended.
assertFalse(task.getIsDone(), "Task should start as not isDone");
assertTrue(task.getIsDone(), "Task should be marked as isDone");
* Test if the method testMarkTaskAsUnDone is working as intended.
assertTrue(task.getIsDone(), "Task should be isDone after marking it");
assertFalse(task.getIsDone(), "Task should be undone after marking it undone");
